newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW-DEC close to Europe downsizing.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-DEC close to Europe downsizing.

text.p: Digital Equipment Corp Chief Financial Officer Vin Mullarkey said he expects "an imminent" agreement to restructure and downsize operations in either France or Germany.

"The areas that have the most work to do...with respect to restructuring happen to be Germany and France," he said. "Because we have been involved in these discussions for an extended period of time to date, we have fallen behind in terms of the restructuring adjustments required."
Efforts to downsize operations in those two countries, as Digital has done worldwide, have been hampered by the countries' complex labour laws and strong unions, he said.
"I'd rather not be specific, but I think that in one case it's imminent, in another case I don't know when it is, hopefully soon," Mullarkey told Reuters in an interview.
He declined to say if the imminent agreement was either in France or Germany, but said he hopes the deal and its implementation could be wrapped up in "a couple of quarters."
Digital has continually downsized over the last few years from 95,000 jobs in 1990 and, in the lastest quarter, cut about 1,100 jobs to 55,900 employees worldwide.
The $14 billion computer company announced plans in 1994 to cut 2,000 jobs from its German unit as part of its broader plan to eliminate 20,000 jobs.
Dozens of workers from Digital's units in Europe showed up at the company's annual meeting in Boston in November to protest the company's downsizing and growth strategy.
Digital's highly public efforts to trim its operations in France and Germany contributed to weaker than expected results from Europe in the second quarter ended December 28, he said.
The continent accounted for about 45 percent or about $1.5 billion of its total operating revenues of $3.36 billion in the second quarter, he said.
Weaker results from France and Germany overshadowed good returns from the United Kingdom and Italy, he said.

Mullarkey said he was encouraged from recent third quarter sales of computer systems powered by its 64-bit Alpha microprocessor, and expected those sales to show a year-over-year rise in the second half of the year.

"We're very much encouraged about the front-log in sales activity that's going on in the marketplace," Mullarkey told Reuters in an interview. "These are orders that are pending to close. Both sequentially and year-over-year, I would expect to see improvement in growth in the second half," he said.
Earlier, Digital reported just one percent growth year-over-year in the second quarter in Alpha sales.
